Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: Making Point Clouds Useful for Earth Science
Award.AbstractNarration: This collaborative project between Idaho State University (ISU), Utah State University (USU), and USFS Rocky Mountain Research Station (RMRS) will develop the next generation of analytical and processing tools for new airborne and ground-based LiDAR monitoring data. The tools will help earth scientists and natural resource managers exploit these data streams to address some of our most pressing environmental questions and management challenges. The software tools will target Earth Science-specific analysis of 3-D point cloud data from platforms like airborne LiDAR (ALS), ground-based LiDAR (TLS), multi-beam SONAR (MBS), and/or Structure from Motion (SfM). The tool development will scale-up existing documented and proven algorithms to be more accessible, as well as build new algorithms that are necessary to address emerging challenges such as change detection analysis from repeat surveys, improved bare earth surface generation, and novel fusion of point clouds collected from different platforms (e.g. ALS and TLS). The new software will be developed collaboratively between geoscientists and computer scientists to optimize performance when handling the large and often problematic data volumes associated with point clouds. This work will provide a suite of community software that will permit innovative and potentially transformative data analysis with the potential to enhance our understanding of numerous earth surface processes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Every day, millions of people browse a plethora of maps on their phones, tablets and personal computers.  Users have become accustomed to more and more maps, with ever more detail, and higher resolution imagery and 3D map features anywhere on earth. Scientists have exploited these high-resolution datasets to make new discoveries about how our earth’s surface evolves and responds to major disturbances ranging from floods and earthquakes to our land use activities. Underlying these maps and backing up these discoveries have been high-resolution point clouds. Point clouds are simply 3D representations of individual point measurements (in x,y,z coordinates) that record the precise locations of the objects they represent (e.g. earth’s surface). The visualization of point clouds have captured the imaginations of both the public and scientists, because they are a fully immersive, 3D representation of the environments they represent.  In short, they look just like the real world because billions to trillions of precisely located points so tightly spaced look just like the real world they are intended to abstract. Direct measurements can be made from these samples, and 3D models can be constructed from point clouds to simplify these things. However exciting these point clouds are as platforms for discovery, they represent a serious analytical challenge to scientists because conventional software and algorithms fall apart when dealing with that volume of data. With the generous support of NSF, this research project was focused on developing software that makes it easier for earth scientists to analyze point clouds.  

Advances in remote sensing with technologies like LiDaR, multi-beam SoNAR and structure-from motion (SFM) photogrammetry have proliferated the availability of point clouds and the ease of acquisition of such data. SFM, in particular, is exciting because anybody with a camera or cell phone can take a series of overlapping photos and use a App to now create such point clouds. Unfortunately, the tools with which we analyze such data have not kept up. We use such data to model topography of the earth’s surface, estimate biomass (e.g. vegetation), and measure changes in the processes shaping our planet. In this project, we redesigned several software applications from outdated platforms into open-source, well documented, and more efficient software packages to handle the challenges these point clouds pose to scientists. This project closed a critical knowledge gap hindering discovery from these data sets. We taught several workshops targeted at scientists who work with this data to provide training in how to exploit the new software we developed. We created well-documented, open-source code for others to leverage and easy to use software interfaces. We also disseminated findings from this methodological effort in peer-reviewed scholarly literature. The broader impacts of this project include open-source, free-ware software that can serve the broader commercial geomatics and e-commerce communities that leverage geo-located analytics.
